entry.title: A Strategic Advantage of Transforming Your Supply Chain with SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP)

For business and technology leaders, the time to modernize legacy supply chain systems is now. SAP Integrated Business Planning (IBP) offers a robust, future-proof solution that delivers tangible benefits.

  • One Source of Truth: SAP IBP provides a common data model across strategic, tactical, and operational planning, eliminating silos and ensuring consistency from end-to-end.
  • AI-Powered Network Insights: Embedded AI with Conversational, Agentic and network capabilities enable advanced planning beyond your organizational boundaries, both upstream and downstream, for smarter, more proactive decisions.

  • Self-Service & Flexibility: Business users can independently make changes, generate reports, and conduct analytics without constant IT intervention. Planners can even execute data and network changes in the live system.

  • Continuous Innovation: SAP's strong commitment to investment means quarterly feature releases, near-zero downtime upgrades, and a roadmap shaped by customer feedback, ensuring your supply chain stays ahead of the curve.

The Bottom Line:

SAP IBP is not just another planning tool; it is a comprehensive platform that empowers your organization with real-time visibility, intelligent decision-making, and unparalleled agility. Investing in SAP IBP means investing in a supply chain that can adapt, innovate, and drive significant business value.

entry.title: The Next Industrial Revolution: AI Agents At The Heart Of Transformation
entry.content:
The manufacturing sector has always been at the forefront of innovation. From the steam engine to the assembly line, each leap has redefined what’s possible on the shop floor. Today, we stand at the threshold of another seismic shift—one powered not just by machines, but by intelligence itself.

The World Economic Forum’s latest whitepaper, “Frontier Technologies in Industrial Operations: The Rise of Artificial Intelligence Agents,” paints a compelling picture of this new era.

Why Now? The Case for Frontier Technologies

Industrial operations have long relied on innovations such as robotics and the industrial internet of things (IIoT) to drive productivity and efficiency. But the challenges facing manufacturers today are as complex as they are urgent. Labor shortages, rising costs, volatile supply chains, and the relentless push for sustainability are all converging. Manufacturers must not only optimize cost and efficiency but also adapt to rapid change, ensure resilience, and meet sustainability goals.

Traditional technologies, while powerful, are no longer enough to meet these demands. The answer lies in embracing what the WEF call “frontier technologies." Those that push the boundaries of what’s possible and unlock new forms of collaborative intelligence between humans and machines.

But why the focus on AI agents, and why now? The answer is simple: AI agents are not just another tool in the digital toolbox. They represent a new paradigm—one where software and robots can autonomously perceive, decide, and act, freeing up human workers to focus on creativity, strategy, and innovation.

The Rise of AI Agents: Virtual and Embodied

Success requires a leap beyond incremental improvement—toward near-autonomous, AI-centric operations that empower people and machines to collaborate seamlessly.

The whitepaper highlights two main types of AI agents driving this transformation:

1. Virtual AI Agents: The Digital Workforce

Virtual AI agents operate within software environments. Think of them as digital colleagues—always on, always learning, and capable of making decisions in real time. These agents can act as assistants, advisers, or even fully autonomous controllers, handling everything from production scheduling to predictive maintenance.

For example, a virtual AI agent might monitor a production line, identify bottlenecks, and automatically adjust workflows to optimize throughput. In supply chain management, these agents can analyze vast amounts of data, anticipate disruptions, and recommend alternative sourcing strategies—often before a human would even notice a problem.

2. Embodied AI Agents: The New Robotics

Embodied AI agents take things a step further. These are robots equipped with advanced AI, capable of perceiving and interacting with the physical world. Unlike traditional robots, which are limited to repetitive, pre-programmed tasks, embodied AI agents can adapt to changing environments, handle complex assemblies, and even collaborate safely alongside human workers.

Picture a robot that can not only pick and place components but also recognize when a part is defective, adjust its grip, or reroute itself to avoid an obstacle—no manual intervention required. This is the promise of embodied AI: robotics that are as flexible and intuitive as the people working beside them.

Redefining the Human Role

One of the most exciting—and perhaps misunderstood—aspects of this transformation is the role of people.

Karim Lakhani, a professor at Harvard Business School, when asked, “Will AI replace humans?”, famously replied, “Of course AI won’t replace humans. But humans with AI will replace humans without AI.”

Far from replacing humans, AI agents are designed to augment human capabilities. As operations become more autonomous, the role of the worker evolves from hands-on operator to orchestrator and innovator.

Strategic Imperatives: Building the Foundations

Of course, realizing the full potential of AI agents requires more than just deploying new technology. Manufacturers must lay strong organizational and technological foundations:

  • Governance and Change Management: Leadership must champion the transformation, fostering a culture of innovation and trust.
  • Skills and Training: Upskilling and reskilling are essential, with a focus on digital literacy, data analysis, and collaboration.
  • Data and Infrastructure: High-quality, accessible data is the lifeblood of AI. Robust connectivity, cybersecurity, and scalable computing power are non-negotiable.
  • Ecosystem Collaboration: No company can do it alone. Partnerships across the value chain—suppliers, technology providers, academia—are key to accelerating innovation.

Looking Ahead: From Experimentation to Transformation

The journey to AI-driven, near-autonomous operations is just beginning. Early adopters are already seeing tangible benefits, from reduced energy consumption to higher product quality and more resilient supply chains. But the real prize lies ahead: a future where manufacturers can respond to change with agility, drive sustainable growth, and empower their people like never before.

As the white paper concludes, manufacturers who embrace frontier technologies today will be the leaders of tomorrow. The Intelligent Age is here—are you ready to seize it?

Want to learn more about how AI-powered supply chains meet today’s needs while preparing for tomorrow? Check out this IDC Analyst Brief: “AI-Powered Business Suite for Supply Chain."

Planners have long dreamed of an uninterrupted flow from proactive attribute-level planning to flawless execution. Now it’s here. The  latest Characteristics-Based Planning (CBP) in IBP seamlessly orchestrates plans through S/4HANA Segmentation into Manufacturing Planning ePPDS (CDP) — all out of the box — from strategic / tactical planning to detailed production scheduling and execution. All Natively integrated. No workarounds. No data loss. 

From Plan to Production – Attribute-Driven Orchestration Now Out of the Box

Characteristics-Based Planning (CBP) in SAP IBP already empowers planners to manage supply and demand at a granular, attribute level including product and supply chain segments.

We now take this to the next level: CBP plans in IBP can now flow seamlessly through S/4HANA demand supply Segmentation into detailed planning and scheduling in S4HANA Manufacturing planning (ePPDS) running with CDP (characteristics dependent planning) — natively, out of the box!

This is not just integration — it’s end-to-end orchestration. Attributes like version, quality grade, or supply chain segment stay intact from tactical planning to shop floor execution, eliminating manual mapping, reducing errors, and ensuring planning intent is preserved in production. The result? Faster responses to demand changes, optimized sequencing, and execution without translation gaps.

entry.title: Cookbook - SAP Query usage statistics
entry.content:
From the context of the migration of ECC to the S4 HANA, the relevance of query reduction may become more of a necessity rather than just a nice-to-have discipline. The reason pertains to the special nature of queries, as they are ‘generated code’ and not similar to regular custom code. As a whole, making ECC queries compatible with S4 may be a daunting task. Therefore, dedicated efforts will be needed to analyze the usage data of queries so that only the required ones migrate into S4 HANA and not the entire list of queries, as many of them are seldom used or may no longer be needed. The usage will provide quantitative information for IT and business to make an informed decision to determine the queries required for the S4 HANA system.

However, there is no straightforward way to calculate query usage statistics. In this write-up, we will attempt to arrive at a process to calculate the usage statistics of the SAP query.

Step 1: Create a List of Queries

  • Run transaction SQ02: Click on ‘Go To’ à Select ‘Query Directory’ à and run wide open

Step 2: Extract raw data for query usage

  • Run transaction SCMON and select ‘Display data.’

This write-up assumed that there are three ways SAP Query can be called:

  • Direct query call using SQ01
  • Query running in Batch jobs
  • Query called through custom transactions

Usage Data Collection

  • Get usage data for direct call using SQ01 from SCMON using ‘Calling Request Entry Point’ as Type = ‘T’ and Name = ‘SQ01’ (see below)

Next screen

Key steps to be followed:

  • Downloaded the list for ‘Submitted Report’ (or DELETE other Request type rows from downloaded report so that we ONLY get ‘Submitted Report’ in resultant Excel)
  • Concatenate User Group & Query name in a NEW column before Num of Calls column (for easier VLOOKUP later)
  • Get usage data for batch call using jobs from SCMON using ‘Calling Request Entry Point’ as Type = ‘B’ and Name = ‘AQIC*’ (see below)

In the next screen, filter only Procurement Type as ‘SSEL’ (as we only want to know the start of selection)

  • Get usage data for custom transaction call from SCMON using ‘Calling Request Entry Point’ as Type = ‘T’ and Name = ‘all custom tcode’ that calls a SAP query at execution. (see below)

In the output, filter only records with ‘Proc Type’ as SSEL.

Once we extract raw data, the remaining portion of the work pertains to connecting data from different files and deriving intelligence on collective usage/calls of respective queries (hint: use Mid & VLOOKUP functions in Excel).

Ultimately, sum up all usages to get the final usage (sample output)

Conclusion:

This write has considered one of the possible approaches to simplistically arrive at the usage data for SAP queries, several which tend to grow significantly with the complexity of business processes and user requirements. For system migration, specifically in the context of S4 HANA conversion from ECC, reduction of redundant queries can pay substantial dividend.

entry.title: SAP Field Logistics: Next Generation Kitting & Staging for MRO Industries
entry.content:
For any MRO organization (Maintenance, Repair, and Operations), kitting and staging is a core warehouse activity. On the surface, it seems simple. But in reality, it's a web of complexity, often managed by years of accumulated custom code and custom business process. 

Introducing Standard Kitting & Staging in S/4HANA 2023

With the release of S/4HANA 2023 FPS02, the struggle with custom kitting solutions is over. SAP has delivered a standard, industry-focused solution designed specifically for the intricacies of MRO: End-to-End Kitting & Staging with SAP Field Logistics.

This solution was co-designed with customers to address the real-world challenges you face every day. It’s built on six core principles to deliver a unified, streamlined process.

1. Centralize Kitting for Remote Operations Efficiently to build, stage, and dispatch kits from a central warehouse directly to remote or field locations, ensuring the right parts are in the right place at the right time.

2. Handle All Types of Goods Seamlessly Support not only inventory managed materials, but also non inventory stock, rental equipment and supplier provided items as part of services, ensuring full visibility and control across all goods movements

3. Empower Your Field Locations Don’t just ship parts—ship capability. Remote sites can now receive kits, manage kits, add locally held components, and issue the completed kit directly to a maintenance order.

4. Simplify and Standardize Your Processes Whether you operate a single, streamlined plant or manage a complex network of remote locations supported by a supply base, this solution provides a standard, repeatable process to eliminate guesswork and create one version of the truth for your kitting and staging operations.

5. Gain End-to-End Visibility in a Single Place Stop chasing information across different systems. The entire kitting lifecycle—from creation and staging to dispatch and final issuance—is tracked in a single, accessible repository, giving you unprecedented control and insight. 

6. Scale for Your Environment This isn't a rigid, one-size-fits-all tool. The solution is designed to scale and adapt, supporting various warehouse management setups including Inventory Management (IM), Extended Warehouse Management (EWM), and even hybrid combinations depending on your organisation.

A Future-Proof Foundation for Your MRO Warehouse

By embedding this critical MRO process directly into the S/4HANA core, SAP has delivered a solution that is robust, scalable, and future proof. You can finally retire that aging custom code, move forward with confidence using a standard SAP solution at the base.

This is more than just a new feature; it's a new foundation for operational excellence in your MRO supply chain.

From Order to Staged Kit: A Look at the New Process

So, how does it actually work? The entire process is designed to be intuitive and integrated with maintenance and project business process.  And it all begins exactly where it should: with the demand from the field. 

Step 1: The Kit is Born from the Demand Signal It all starts with a Work Order or Network Order; the kit is automatically created and updated. As the requested materials arrive at the Supply Base, using the Field Logistics Cross-Docking process, the system automatically triggers the tracking milestones and begins the process of bringing everything together.

What truly sets this solution apart is its flexibility in defining the kit. You are no longer locked into a single method like in the past. At the demand plant level, you can define a kit based:

  • The Work Order/Network Order Header: Perfect for bundling all materials where work is planned and scheduled at the header.
  • A Work Order/Network Order Operation: Ideal for creating kits for specific phases or tasks within a more detailed planning and scheduling environment. 
  • A flexible definition via BAdI: For unique business requirements, this allows you to implement custom logic while remaining within the standard framework.

Step 2: Augment the Kit with Local Inventory The process doesn't stop with the initial cross dock. If required, you can easily supplement the base kit by adding stock directly from local base inventory or as more cross docking occurs. This hybrid approach allows you to combine centrally sourced materials with locally available parts for maximum efficiency, speed and tracking.

Step 3: Pack, Stage, and Track with Precision Once complete, the kit can be packed into standard Field Logistics objects like Containers or Packages.

Crucially, every object—including the delivery items —can be assigned to a specific staging location or bin via a dedicated standard field via the Pack Containers (F5786)app. This eliminates guesswork and "lost" kits. The result is pinpoint accuracy on the warehouse floor, where everyone knows exactly what a kit contains, where it is, and which job it’s for.

Flexibility at the Edge: Managing Kits Upon Arrival

The journey doesn't end when the kit leaves the central warehouse. A core strength of SAP Field Logistics is its ability to track the Supply Chain end to end. The solution is designed to handle several common scenarios:

Scenario 1: The "Base Kit" Handover

In this model, all components have been kitted at the central base. The kit arrives at the remote location fully prepared. The process here is built for speed and simplicity:

  • Receive: The remote site performs a simple goods receipt for the complete kit.
  • Stage: The kit is stored, ready for the job.  The kit can be assigned to a specific staging location or bin via a dedicated standard field.

Scenario 2: The "Remote Kit" Assembly

This scenario is common in industries like Mining or Land-Based Operations where remote sites are highly self-sufficient. Here, no physical goods are shipped from the base. Instead:

  • Demand Signal: The demand is to be supplied fully from the remote site.
  • Local Assembly: The kit is assembled and managed entirely at the remote location using its locally held inventory. This empowers the remote team to take full ownership of the kitting process and support the operations stocking strategy.
  • Stage: The kit is stored, ready for the job.  The kit can be assigned to a specific staging location or bin via a dedicated standard field.

Scenario 3: The "Re-Kit" Hybrid Model

This flexible, hybrid approach offers the best of both worlds. A base kit containing centrally sourced or specialized parts is shipped from the main warehouse. Upon arrival:

  • Receive Base Kit: The initial kit is received at the remote location.
  • Augment Locally: The remote team then adds further components to the kit directly from their local inventory to create the final package.
  • Stage: The kit is stored, ready for the job.  The kit can be assigned to a specific staging location or bin via a dedicated standard field.

This adaptability—from a simple handover to full remote assembly—ensures that no matter your operational model, the system supports your reality on the ground.

Mastering "The Last Mile": Detailed Tracking at the Remote Site

The final journey of a kit—from the remote warehouse shelf to the hands of a technician—is often a logistical black box. This critical phase, aptly named "The Last Mile," is where parts get misplaced, jobs get delayed, and efficiency breaks down. A common problem is the lack of real-time visibility once a kit is "in the system" but not yet in use.

SAP Field Logistics solves this by introducing key tracking milestones for the entire "Last Mile" lifecycle. Now, users can pinpoint exactly where everything is in real-time.

1. Stage - Once a kit item is received or assembled at the remote location, its status is set to Staged. It is officially logged as staged and ready for the job. The kit can be assigned to a specific staging location or bin using a dedicated standard field. The warehouse knows exactly what is ready and precisely where to find it.

2. Drop - As the job start time approaches, the kit needs to move closer to the point of work. When this happens, its status is updated to Dropped. It can then be assigned to a nominated drop point—like a specific laydown yard or workshop area—again using a dedicated standard location field.

3. Issue - This is the final, crucial handover. The kits items status is updated to Issued at the moment the technician formally receives the complete kit. This closes the loop on the logistics process, providing a clear and simple audit trail. It confirms that the right parts were delivered to the right person at the right time, minimizing disputes and ensuring the job can begin without delay.

Unlocking Total Visibility: Answering "Where Is My Stuff?"

In any MRO operation, the question "Where is my stuff?" is asked daily. But "stuff" can mean anything—an individual component, a complex kit for a shutdown, or all the materials for a week's worth of routine maintenance. Answering this question accurately and in real-time has always been a major challenge.

SAP Field Logistics answers this question by tracking every item against extensive, standard milestones, it provides a single source of truth. This critical information is no longer buried in spreadsheets or system tables; it is visualized in intuitive Fiori applications and via exposed API's.

While day-to-day operations are handled in the Manage Kits (F8005) and Manage Logistics (F5082) apps, the consolidated view of this new visibility comes to life in the Logistics Tracking (F7382) app.

First delivered with S/4HANA 2023 FPS00, the Logistics Tracking App has now been specifically enhanced to include the key kitting milestones. This means the "Last Mile" statuses—Stage, Drop, and Issue—are now surfaced directly in this central dashboard.

The result is a single view where planners, supervisors, and technicians can see the real-time status of any component or kit, from the central warehouse all the way to the point of use. The question is no longer "Where is my stuff?" but "What do I need to look at next?"

Five Core Capabilities That Transform MRO Logistics

Having walked through the end-to-end process, from the central warehouse to the final handover, we can see how SAP Field Logistics delivers a set of transformative capabilities that directly address the core challenges of MRO supply chains.

1. A Single, Standardized Process from Warehouse to Worksite For the first time, a single, standard process governs the entire kitting lifecycle. From the initial build in a supply base to augmenting a kit at a remote site and issuing it to a technician, the system provides one unified framework. This eliminates process variations, reduces training overhead, and establishes a foundation for operational excellence across the entire organization.

2. Real-Time, End-to-End Visibility The question "Where is my stuff?" is definitively answered. Through the Logistics Tracking App and dedicated Fiori dashboards, you have a single source of truth. By tracking key milestones like Staged, Dropped, and Issued, you gain complete, real-time visibility into the "Last Mile," enabling better decision-making and proactive control.

3. Flexibility for Real-World Operations This is not a rigid, one-size-fits-all solution. It is built to adapt to your reality. Whether you need to define a kit by an entire work order or a specific operation, or whether you manage kits centrally, remotely, or through a hybrid model, the solution provides the flexibility to support your specific business needs.  For example - your operation does not drop but issues directly from staging, this is supported.

4. Integration with Core Maintenance and Warehouse Processes SAP Field Logistics is not a standalone module; it is woven into the digital core. It integrates seamlessly with Maintenance Orders, Network Orders, Logistics Execution (LE), Inventory Management (IM), and Extended Warehouse Management (EWM). This ensures data consistency, prevents information silos, and creates a smooth, automated flow from maintenance planning to field execution.

5. Finally Retire Custom Code and Embrace a Clean Core Perhaps the most strategic benefit is the ability to finally retire your expensive, high-risk custom kitting solutions. By moving this critical functionality into the S/4HANA standard, you can eliminate technical debt, simplify future upgrades, and fully embrace a "clean core" strategy. This reduces your total cost of ownership and positions your organization on a future-proof platform for years to come.

Conclusion: The Future is Standard

For years, managing MRO kitting has meant a compromise. Organizations were forced to choose between a standard SAP process that didn't fully meet their needs or investing heavily in complex, custom-coded solutions that created technical debt and upgrade risk. These "Z-solutions," while functional, were brittle, expensive to maintain, and operated in a silo with each customer to define everything including integration.

With the introduction of SAP Field Logistics in S/4HANA, that era is over.

The journey from a fragmented, high-maintenance custom process to a powerful, flexible, and standard solution is no longer a future ambition—it is a present reality. We have seen how Field Logistics provides a single, unified framework to:

  • Define and build kits with flexibility.
  • Manage them across diverse remote site scenarios.
  • Track them through "The Last Mile."
  • Visualize their status in real-time for all stakeholders.

This is more than a new module; it is a fundamental shift in strategy. It is the opportunity to finally retire your custom code, shed decades of technical debt, and embrace a "clean core" architecture. It's a chance to align your operations with a future-proof platform that will evolve with your business, not hold it back.

The path forward is no longer about building a better workaround; it's about leveraging a better standard. The future of MRO logistics isn't custom; it's standard and powered by Field Logistics.

entry.title: Supply Chain Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508
entry.content:
The SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release is here and delivers a broad range of innovations and enhancements across core business processes, focusing on greater automation, improved user experience, and deeper integration to help organizations run more efficiently in a cloud-first environment. Don't miss the highlights blog by Bert Schulze to find out more about the top innovations across the cloud ERP, or find out about the top AI & next-gen ERP features in this post by Yannick Peterschmitt.

With the supply chain specialists and logistics maestros in mind - this blog post dials in on the latest supply chain management features being rolled out in and around the 2508 release. With this release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, supply chain management takes another step forward in agility, intelligence, and integration. This update introduces a range of enhancements designed to optimize end-to-end processes, improve real-time visibility, and support faster decision-making across logistics and operations. Whether you're focused on inventory, transport, production, or delivery, the 2508 release brings innovative features that align with today's demand for resilient and sustainable supply chains. Check out the release video below for the quick summary of selected features, or read on below for more detail and some comprehensive E2E demos!

 

Core Logistics Topics

We'll kick things off with the latest core logistics features release in 2508, designed to enhance your fundamental supply chain execution and planning processes.


Inventory Management
Support for Copied Movement Types in SAP Fiori Apps for Goods movement

Flexibility to adapt business processes is a vital aspect of a dynamic supply chain, and custom movement types in SAP S/4HANA Cloud offer just that. These custom adaptations of standard movement types serve to bridge gaps where predefined scenarios may not meet particular business needs, allowing tailor-made solutions for unique business requirements. The SAP FIORI apps which support custom movement types have been extended to include Manage stock (F1062), Transfer Stock – In Plant (F1061) and Transfer Stock – Cross Plan (F1957).

One prominent use case for custom movement types arises when there’s a need to post goods movements to different General Ledger (GL) account determinations. While standard movement types seamlessly integrate with key SAP FIORI apps for goods movement, setting up a custom movement type involves a simple two-step process: first, copy an existing standard movement type in your configuration environment, assigning it a new character key starting with 9, x, y, or z, while adding any additional necessary details. The next step is to implement the custom Business Add-In (BAdI) MMIM_GR4XY_PROVIDE_DATA. This facilitates the availability of this newly created movement type alongside standard options in the supported FIORI apps, allowing users the flexibility to select the movement type that best fits their operational needs. This approach not only maximizes the system’s adaptability but also ensures streamlined and efficient management of specialized business processes.

For a step-by-step description of the implementing this process, check out this blog post.


(fig: Custom movement types displayed in Transfer Stock – In Plant)

New FIORI App - Manage Physical Inventory Document Items

In Inventory Management, a key theme of the 2508 release is the strategic modernization of the user experience to boost performance and analytical capabilities. With the 2508 release, we introduce the new app “Manage Physical Inventory document Items” (F8634) as a successor to transaction MI20 “Process physical inventory count results”, which has been deprecated. The experience switch is enabled on both apps, enabling users with the correct authorizations to switch between them with ease. The new app provides a clearer overview of physical inventory tasks, directly in the list view saving users time. The new app’s functionality doesn’t stop there; it empowers you to fine-tune your workflow through customization options. For instance, adding fields such as storage bin information can streamline precise material location management. Moreover, with enhanced filtering capabilities, you can now delve deeper into your data, allowing for a more nuanced analysis of inventory differences. With these improvements, transitioning to the Manage Physical Inventory Item List (F8634) app not only future-proofs your inventory operations but also enriches the way you interact with your inventory data.

Support for Barcode Scanning for Additional Goods Issues (Project / Asset)

A further new feature in inventory management – the "Manage Stock" app has been enhanced with barcode scanning for goods movements for both project stock and assets. New movement types for this stock have been introduced to streamline and optimize your inventory management processes. Efficiency gains come with the capability to leverage composite barcode scanning within the app. Users can select the new stock change options for goods issue projects or assets in the manage stock app, then assign the related WBS element or asset or sub-asset number respectively. This enhancement translates to faster and more efficient processing of inventory adjustments, reducing not just the margin for error but also the time spent managing inventory tasks. Overall, these updates are set to greatly enhance stock management workflows, making them not only more efficient but also more aligned with contemporary business needs.

Cross-Plant Transfer Posting with Item Lines

Item lists are a collection of material items that you can process together in warehouse or inventory processes. Whilst this is a familiar feature, with 2508 we have expanded where item lists are deployed to enhance inventory processes and introduce them to the “Transfer Stock – Cross Plan” application. Here, it is now possible to create a list of multiple items for stock transfer, enabling users to post items in one step and on one material document. This provides greater visibility as you see all transferred items in one list across plants and improves efficiency when checking movement history for several materials on one list.

Extensibility Updates

Enhancing process flexibility, this release introduces new extensibility options for material reservation applications. Businesses can now add custom fields to the user interfaces and underlying business logic for creating, changing, and displaying reservations. This allows companies to capture and process specific information relevant to their unique operational needs directly within the reservation document. For example, a business could add a field to track a project code or a specific reason for the reservation, improving data richness, enhancing reporting, and ensuring that custom process requirements are met without complex workarounds.

Handling Unit Management

Key to managing packaging, tracking and handling goods throughout your supply chain, we also have some updates to Handling Unit Management functionality. With this release, we introduce two key enhancements to Handling Units APIs.

Assign Serial Numbers to Existing Handling Units

A key innovation in this release is the enhancement of the Handling Unit (HU) OData API, which now supports the assignment of serial numbers to already created handling units—a critical capability that was previously missing. This enhancement addresses a functional gap left by previous API operations that only supported packing and posting goods receipt for production orders. Now, before a goods receipt is posted, serial numbers can be assigned to HUs via the API, streamlining processes where HUs are prepared in advance. This capability ensures better alignment with manufacturing and warehouse workflows where serialization is required before physical goods receipt.

The updated API enables serial number assignment through two supported scenarios: either by generating serial numbers automatically at production order creation (based on the serial number profile), or by receiving them from an external system via API communication. The API intelligently checks whether a production order already includes serial numbers and defaults to these when assigning to HUs, ensuring data consistency. This innovation not only supports developer extensibility and integration flexibility but also significantly enhances traceability and compliance in serialized environments—especially in regulated industries.

Enhanced Security for Production Supply Area Data

To strengthen integration security, the Production Supply Area (PSA) OData API now supports OAuth 2.0 authentication, aligning with modern SAP security protocols and standards. This enhancement ensures a more secure, token-based authorization process, enabling third-party applications to access SAP S/4HANA Cloud resources without exposing sensitive credentials in the payload. OAuth 2.0 improves trust and compliance for integrations, especially in multi-system landscapes where security and granular access control are critical.

This update also improves connectivity with SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), making it easier to securely link external applications to SAP S/4HANA Cloud for PSA-related data access. Applications can now request specific scopes of access to user data, supporting role-based security and limiting unnecessary data exposure. With this change, customers gain more controlled, secure, and scalable integration patterns for managing production supply data across platforms.


Delivery Management

RAP events are standardized notifications that signal changes in business objects, enabling flexible and loosely coupled extensions in SAP S/4HANA Cloud. With the latest innovation, RAP events are now available for outbound delivery, inbound delivery, and customer returns delivery, empowering developers working with embedded extensibility (Developer Extensibility) to enhance their projects directly on-stack. You can implement custom logic to consume events such as Created, Changed, or Deleted for these delivery documents, as well as more granular events like Picking Status Changed or Item Created for outbound deliveries. This makes it possible to react instantly to delivery-related changes in your extensions built with the ABAP environment, while leveraging standardized events that increase development efficiency and consistency across solutions


Order Promising

Conversational Backorder Processing with Joule (Beta)

Imagine running a complex backorder processing (BOP) run by simply having a conversation. With the 2508 release, this is now a reality! Introduced initially as a BETA feature, from CFD release 2508.2, all users with a base license of Joule can leverage AI to automate BOP checks and processing.

Using simple, natural language commands in a chat, you can check stock situations and initiate a BOP run. For example, you can tell Joule you want to run BOP for a specific product and plant. In the background, Joule will prompt for which strategy you wish to implement with the default selection of “improve”, it creates the necessary BOP segment and variant, and processes the run—skipping multiple manual steps and app-toggling. This is a fantastic leap forward in simplifying a powerful process, and we are excited to hear how adopting this feature has enhanced your experience!

 

 

Display Product Availability Enhancements

With the 2508 release, we bid farewell to jumping between various transactions when seeking a comprehensive overview of product availability. The new Display Product Availability Fiori app is here to modernize and simplify your experience. Instead of scattered views, you now get all relevant availability information in a single, intuitive three-panel layout. At a glance, you see a high-level summary of available quantities, a detailed drill-down of MRP elements such as stocks and requirements, and a clear "Scope of Check" panel showing which supply and demand elements are included. With this release, the app now also includes the Analyze Product Availability feature. This allows you to dive deeper into product availability at the plant level. You can easily analyze product availability by selecting the plant you want to review and the app gives you a clear overview of confirmations, showing why certain quantities are available on specific dates and how concurrent demands impact stock or receipts. This makes it easier to respond to customer needs and share insights with stakeholders.

To dig deeper, you can drill down on MRP elements, adjust the date range to see planned changes, or view the scope of check to understand exactly which stocks, receipts, and requirements are considered. Horizon settings further explain why available quantities may appear positive, zero, or even negative. By surfacing these factors in one place, the app provides transparency and confidence in managing product availability.

See the new enhancements in the below demo video:

 

What’s more, with CFD release 2508.1, we extend these MRP features beyond the plant category to also account for storage locations. Conduct analysis and drill down on the same elements based on storage location with the same simplified UI panels within the Display Product Availability app.

Activating ATP Check for Subcontracting Outbound Delivery Creation

Many customers working with the subcontracting purchasing process face a key challenge: preventing outbound delivery notes from being created when there is no stock available. In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud release 2508, we address this challenge by enabling ATP checks for subcontracting outbound delivery creation. Until now, the ATP (Available-to-Promise) check was not triggered for subcontracting deliveries, meaning delivery notes could still be generated even if stock levels are zero.

This gap can create inefficiencies, as users may be instructed to pick items that simply aren’t available in the warehouse. For companies which outsource parts of their manufacturing through subcontractors, accurate stock management is essential to keep production flowing. It is critical that only available and ready-to-pick stock is passed into subcontracting deliveries. Without validation, discrepancies between SAP and the actual warehouse stock can lead to delays, wasted effort, and disruptions in the supply chain.

By enabling configuration of the ATP check flag in the 2508 release, ATP  check can be enforced for subcontracting deliveries, ensuring that stock availability is validated before outbound deliveries are created. The result is clear: consistent order promising across the supply chain, improved accuracy, and smoother end-to-end operations.

 

Transportation Management

Stock transfer with delivery (BME) with warehouse management and transportation management(outbound)

One of the key challenges for supply chain specialists is managing outbound processes efficiently while ensuring seamless coordination between warehouse and transportation operations. Expanding on the outbound process defined in scope item “stock transfer with delivery (BME)”, with the 2502.3 release, we integrate both warehouse management and transportation management to streamline stock transfer orders end to end.

Customers can now create intra-company Stock Transport Orders (STOs) that automatically trigger Freight Unit (FU) creation in TM and generate Outbound Deliveries, which are processed through WM for picking, packing, and loading. A key new feature is dynamic delivery splitting—if not all handling units (HUs) can be loaded, the system automatically creates a new outbound delivery for the remaining goods. Additionally, TM now supports stock transfers from WM-managed locations, and includes batch-managed material data in freight documents. These updates provide customers with a fully integrated, automated logistics flow that improves supply chain visibility, operational efficiency, and flexibility—especially in dynamic warehouse and transport environments.

 

Enabling key user extensibility of freight document user interfaces

This feature introduces the flexibility to adapt the user interface of applications based on Web Dynpro ABAP (WDA)and Floorplan Manager (FPM), giving your business greater control over how classic application screens look and function. It addresses the common challenge of rigid UIs by empowering key users and technical teams to configure freight document interfaces—such as adding or removing fields, adjusting layouts, or rearranging elements—to match specific business needs. The feature allows you to adjust the structure of main UI pages, including the sequence and titles of tabs, as well as tailor the content of specific areas—for example, changing the order of fields, updating field labels, or hiding elements that aren’t relevant. With this update, we’re delivering clear value in supporting the customizing of UIs which better reflect your company’s specific use cases and processes, enabling users to interact with the applications more productively.

 

Warehouse Management

Keeping up with the Suite-First strategy, in 2508 much has been done to ensure that Warehouse Management functionality supports all scope items and process variations available within SAP S/4HANA Cloud ERP. Take a look in more detail in this blog by Christian Ries. Below, we’ll focus on a few new features we want to highlight in particular.

Stock Removal Strategy for direct goods movement postings (EWM)

A much requested feature which we’re happy to roll out to customers, the Post Goods Movement app now includes a new button that triggers the stock removal strategy. This automatically determines the optimal storage bin, handling unit, and batch or serial number when posting a direct goods issue. Available for goods issue postings in manufacturing orders and reservations, this feature streamlines the process by aligning with your stock removal strategy to select the best storage bin. The result is greater efficiency and accuracy when posting goods issues, reducing manual effort and errors. Specifically designed for goods issue of production components, this enhancement ensures that the right stock is used at the right time—supporting faster, more reliable production execution.

Summarized JIT Calls 

This feature enables efficient handling of outbound deliveries that reference summarized Just-in-Time (JIT) calls within Warehouse Management. By integrating seamlessly with JIT processes, it ensures that deliveries comply with configured underdelivery and overdelivery tolerances. Leveraging the built-in warehouse management capabilities—such as picking, packing, staging, and loading—you can now handle outbound processing of summarized JIT calls (scope item 2EM) more effectively. Outbound deliveries with JIT references can be easily selected and processed within warehouse management, improving efficiency, accuracy, and reliability, while directly benefiting customers through more consistent and timely deliveries.

 

Integrating Extended Warehouse Management


Many of our customers have sophisticated supply chains and warehouse processes which involve central hubs and different satellite entities. With 2508, we are excited to roll out an integration scenario which will make managing such a set up much simpler. With the new communication scenario, Logistics - S/4HANA Extended Warehouse Management Integration (SAP_COM_0A58), you can now integrate a decentralized Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) system in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition with your SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. This integration provides essential services to distribute and maintain inbound and outbound deliveries across hybrid landscapes. This helps your organization leverage existing EWM investments while expanding your cloud footprint, ensuring seamless data flow for critical delivery processes.

In-house Repair with Warehouse Management

A common challenge in after-sales service is managing the logistics of returning repaired products back to customers quickly and efficiently. With the 2508 release, we have enhanced the in-house repair process (scope item 3XK) by integrating warehouse management. This should streamline this process enabling companies to more efficiently define and execute their in-house repair workflows.

The process begins when a returned product is received and logged into the warehouse, where serial numbers are verified and the item is moved to a clarification zone for inspection. If an in-house repair is needed, a follow-up activity is created, ensuring the right material and serial number are tracked through the repair cycle. Once the product is fixed, an outbound delivery order is generated, and warehouse management takes over again to pick, pack, stage, and load the item for shipment back to the customer.



By leveraging warehouse management capabilities, organizations can optimize every step of the return—from picking and packing the repaired product to staging and loading it for shipment. This ensures accuracy, reduces manual effort, and speeds up turnaround times, ultimately improving the customer experience while driving efficiency in logistics operations. See the full process in the below End-to-End demo.


Summary

The 2508 release highlights in the supply chain management area of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition should help optimize your supply chain and logistics processes. entry.title: 5C Framework for SAP Integrated Business Planning Data Validation Strategy
entry.content:
Why Data Quality in SAP IBP?

The success of SAP IBP hinges on the availability of quality data from all relevant sources across the organization. Without this foundation of high-quality data, the collaborative and cross-functional nature of IBP will be severely hampered, leading to flawed insights, poor decisions, and an ineffective planning process that fails to deliver the expected business benefits.

Therefore, organizations implementing SAP IBP must prioritize data quality initiatives as a critical component of their implementation and ongoing operations to ensure that they can leverage the full potential of the integrated planning platform. This often involves establishing data governance processes, data quality and validation routines, and ongoing monitoring of data quality across all the heterogeneous systems and departments.

I, as an IBP solution architect and consultant, have seen data quality impact on various functions and across all levels.

1. Accurate Forecasting and Demand Planning:

  • IBP heavily relies on accurate demand forecasts to plan production, inventory, and supply chain activities.
  • Poor data quality in historical sales data, market trends, or customer information will lead to inaccurate forecasts, resulting in either overstocking (leading to waste and costs) or understocking (leading to lost sales and customer dissatisfaction).

2. Reliable Supply Planning:

  • Accurate demand forecasts and reliable data on current inventory levels, lead times, and supplier capabilities are essential for effective supply planning.
  • Inaccurate data in these areas can lead to production delays, material shortages, and increased costs.

3. Effective Financial Planning:

  • IBP integrates financial planning with operational plans. Accurate financial data, including costs, revenues, and profitability, is crucial for making sound financial decisions.
  • Poor data quality can lead to inaccurate financial projections and budgets, impacting the overall financial health of the organization.

4. Informed Decision-Making:

  • IBP aims to provide a holistic view of the business, enabling informed decision- making across different departments.
  • If the underlying data is inaccurate, incomplete, or inconsistent, the insights derived from IBP will be flawed, leading to poor strategic and operational decisions.

5. Seamless Collaboration:

  • IBP fosters collaboration among different departments. Consistent and reliable data ensures that all stakeholders are working with the same information, facilitating effective communication and alignment.
  • Data quality issues can create friction and mistrust among teams, hindering the collaborative nature of IBP.

6. Performance Measurement and Improvement:

  •  IBP involves monitoring key performance indicators (KPIs) to track progress and identify areas for improvement.
  • Accurate data is essential for measuring performance accurately and identifying the root causes of any issues. Poor data quality can lead to misleading performance metrics and ineffective improvement initiatives.

Data quality is paramount for IBP success. Without high quality data, the benefits of IBP cannot be fully realized, and the organization risks making poor decisions that can negatively impact its bottom line and overall performance.

 

5C Framework for SAP IBP Data Validation

The proposed 5Cs are the core traits which determine whether the data is fit for the SAP IBP planning purpose. By adhering to these 5C's, organizations can improve their data quality, leading to more reliable insights, better decision-making, and increased operational efficiency. It is important to note that maintaining high data quality is an ongoing process that requires continuous monitoring and improvement.

  1. Conformity
  2. Consistency
  3. Completeness
  4. Comprehensiveness
  5. Concurrency

Figure 1: 5Cs of Data Quality Framework

1.      Conformity

This aspect of the SAP IBP data quality ensures that data adheres to predefined rules and standards regarding format, type, and size.

  1. Case for the predefined rules: In SAP IBP there are predefined special characters which cannot be used. (Refer to SAP note: 2453887)

Figure 2: SAP Note 2453887 listing restricted characters

b. Case for the format, type, and size: In SAP IBP, each attribute that exists has a format, type and size associated. All the value must comply by the formats, types, and sizes otherwise there is a risk of the job failure with fatal error.

FORMAT TYPESIZE
NVARCHAR (with/without Only Upper Case)  Character Length (max length up to 450)
DECIMAL    18,6
INTEGER      Whole Number
TIMESTAMP        YYYYMMDD hh:mm:ss.000

Table 1: SAP IBP Format Types and Sizes

2.      Consistency

This aspect of the SAP IBP data quality ensures uniformity, coherency, and avoidance of contradictions across different data sources, planning areas, data objects and time periods. Consistency ensures that information is uniform and comparable throughout the organization. However, when SAP IBP receives data from multiple sources such as ERP systems, data warehouses, cloud-based data lakes, third-party systems, home-grown applications, production planning system, transport planning system and planners' Excel sheets, maintaining data consistency becomes key area to focus on. This diversity of data sources, if ignored, can lead to discrepancies in data formats, definitions, and quality, potentially compromising the accuracy of SAP IBP's planning processes.

To ensure consistency in master Data SAP IBP provides some in-build checks which must be configured like attribute checks and mandatory attributes.

Figure 3: IBP Master Data object consistency checks with attribute checks

For IBP transactional data, we can ensure consistency by adding a mandatory attribute from compound master data in planning level for the key figure. Such configuration avoids inconsistent transactional data flowing into the system.

Figure 4: IBP mandatory attribute used in base planning level of key figures

It is important to understand that SAP IBP does not inherently guarantee consistency within object hierarchies such as Product, Customer, and Location hierarchies. Therefore, the Customer and System Integrator's consultants must collaboratively develop a strategy to ensure consistency in parent-child relationships (1:N cardinality) for hierarchical data objects. This proactive approach is crucial for accurate aggregation and disaggregation, enabling effective and actionable insights.

Figure 5: IBP Data Hierarchy with Parent Child relationship

To ensure the correct parent-child relationships, one of the approaches is to extract a parent-child combination in excel sheet and create a pivot table on unique records. All children must have single parent otherwise aggregation and disaggregation will be wrong, leading to wrong planning results.

3.      Completeness

The completeness of data refers to the state where all the necessary and relevant data points required for the specific planning process and the overall IBP framework are present and available within the system. It means that there are no significant gaps or missing pieces of information that hinder the ability to perform accurate analysis, generate reliable plan and make informed decisions.

Figure 6: Incomplete/Broken Supply Network

Figure 6 clearly demonstrates the incompleteness of the data from the supply chain network where capacity data at resource is missing along with a broken network with respect to missing lanes. Such an incomplete dataset will generate improper planning results.

To avoid the incomplete data flowing into the IBP system, we need to develop interfaces outside the IBP system using ABAP validations in SAP S4 or BW4HANA or CIDS to identify the incompleteness and generate a report for correction by clients IT Team / Data Management Team. By using the "Manage Rules for Master Data Maintenance" feature in IBP, we can effectively define the correct "Subnetwork" node and diagnose which node is disrupting the supply chain network. Example: All Location product combinations to pass through following checks updating a corresponding custom attribute which finally impacts the subnetwork.

1.Inbound: Master data rule to check for Location source in Location Source object.

2.Inbound: Master data rule to check source production in Source Production Header object.

3.Outbound: Master data rule to check Ship-from with product combination in Location Source object.

4.Outbound: Master data rule to check Location Product combination in Source Customer object.

5.Outbound: Master data rule to check Location Product combination in production source Item.

* This is just an approach which may differ from project to project and network schema variations.

4.      Comprehensiveness

Data Comprehensiveness refers to the degree to which all the necessary and relevant data required to support the IBP processes, models, and overall planning objectives is available, accessible, and integrated within the IBP system. It goes beyond just having completeness. It entails:

  • Breadth of Data: Having data across all relevant dimensions and business areas that are within the scope of the IBP implementation. This includes data related to sales, demand, supply, inventory, finance, and potentially other relevant areas.
  • Depth of Data: Having data at the appropriate level of detail required for the planning activities, ensuring that data is available for all the products, customers, locations, and other relevant entities that are included in the IBP planning scope.

Figure 7: Data Comprehensiveness covers all the IBP data objects including each attribute

Example for missing comprehensiveness can be missing key attribute values like Lead Times, Lot Sizes, rounding values, Quota split ratios, Cost rates, On-hand Inventory for few combinations only in IBP system. It may cause unreliable planning results. To systematically capture all such cases, IBP custom alerts can be valuable to report missing attributes. Along with this the IBP’s feature like “Discover Pattern using Machine Learning”, “Find Numerical Outliers” can help identify the completeness gaps.

Figure 8: IBP Feature for data pattern discovery and numeric outliers

5.      Concurrency

Every business executive stives to strike alignment between business strategic planning and execution system. Concurrency in planning and execution represents a paradigm shift from traditional sequential approaches, enabling organizations to adapt dynamically in fast-paced environments. This methodology interweaves planning and action in real time, allowing adjustments based on evolving conditions while maintaining operational continuity. The planning and execution should be coupled like Yin-Yang.

Figure 9: Yin-Yang of Planning and Execution

From IBP planning perspective the concurrency is achieved while keeping it updated with the latest execution data. The execution data represents the latest customer orders, internal goods movements between Plants and RDCs, latest production orders, and vendor related purchase orders are integrated daily or even lesser frequency to IBP. This enables IBP planners to have complete visibility of the execution system, and they can align the plan or coordinate with execution teams to keep working on the same organizational objective.

Conclusive Remarks

At its core, the success of SAP IBP depends entirely on high-quality data. Without a solid foundation of accurate, reliable information, the platform's ability to facilitate collaboration and integrated planning is undermined. This leads to flawed insights, poor decision-making, and ultimately, a failure to deliver the expected business benefits.

Key impacts of poor data quality include:

  • Inaccurate forecasting and supply planning, resulting in issues like over- or under-stocking.

  • Flawed financial planning and projections.

  • Uninformed decisions because the underlying data is inconsistent or incomplete.

  • Friction among teams due to a lack of trust in shared data.

  • Misleading performance metrics, which hinder effective improvement initiatives.

Therefore, prioritizing data quality through robust governance, validation, and monitoring is not just a best practice—it's essential for organizations to fully leverage SAP IBP's potential. The 5C Validation Framework (Conformity, Consistency, Completeness, Comprehensiveness, Concurrency) provides a core set of traits to ensure data is fit for purpose, leading to more reliable insights and greater operational efficiency.

entry.title: Is Your Traceability Strategy Ready for 2027? Discover SAP Corporate Serialization
entry.content:
Product traceability is no longer just a regulatory requirement; it has become a strategic imperative. Today, it underpins risk management, accelerates recalls, and builds consumer trust in increasingly complex supply chains. A robust traceability strategy safeguards brand integrity and drives competitive advantage in a market that demands transparency.

Historically, industries relied on SAP Auto-ID Infrastructure (AII) and SAP Object Event Repository (OER) on the NetWeaver platform as the standard for traceability, turning compliance into operational efficiency. But with SAP ending mainstream maintenance for NetWeaver applications by 2027, forward-thinking companies must plan their next move.

The strategic path forward is migration to SAP Corporate Serialization. More than an upgrade, it’s a transformative step that unifies AII and OER capabilities into a modern, integrated platform designed for today’s global supply chains. This transition future-proofs operations, meets evolving transparency requirements, and positions businesses for sustainable growth.

This article will guide supply chain leaders through this critical shift, addressing the most pressing questions about SAP Corporate Serialization:

  • What is SAP Corporate Serialization?
  • What capabilities does SAP Corporate Serialization offer?
  • What are the use cases of SAP Corporate Serialization?
  • What is the business value of SAP Corporate Serialization?

 

What is SAP Corporate Serialization?

SAP Corporate Serialization is a secure, private cloud-based SaaS solution that layers seamlessly on top of existing SAP ERP systems, consolidating the capabilities of SAP AII and SAP OER into a single, cohesive platform. It provides scalable serialization management, integrating with shop-floor systems and meeting global regulatory requirements.

The solution enables end-to-end visibility across the entire product lifecycle; from subcomponents to finished goods; transforming traceability from static records into a dynamic narrative. It authenticates products, combats counterfeiting, and manages both batch and logistics unit distribution. By unifying serialized data and events across suppliers, manufacturing sites, and customers, and integrating with systems like ERP, WMS, MES, and RFID/barcode technologies, SAP Corporate Serialization captures every event from production to delivery (Figure 1)

Figure 1:- System Landscape with SAP Corporate Serialization

 

What capabilities does SAP Corporate Serialization offer?

1. Central Serial Number Management: Generate flexible alphanumeric, randomized, or product-specific serials and distribute them in bulk, reducing manual effort, ensuring accuracy, and supporting compliance.

2. End-to-End Integration and Extensibility: Connect seamlessly with SAP Business Network, SAP EWM, SAP ECC/S/4HANA, and non-SAP systems (Figure 2), while also extending the solution to accommodate customer-specific requirements and traceability attributes; enhancing operational decision-making and supply chain visibility.

Figure 2: SAP Corporate Serialization Integration Options

3. Automation and Standardization: Automate serialization, reporting, and data exchange; streamlining workflows, enforcing consistent processes, and lowering risk of errors.

4. User Experience and Interfaces Monitoring: Intuitive SAP GUI and FIORI interfaces combined with SAP Application Interface Framework (AIF) monitoring; enabling faster onboarding, real-time transaction oversight, and quick resolution of exceptions.

5. Future-Proof, Cost-Efficient Architecture: Supports GS1, EPCIS, and other formats like IMEI, UID, and UDI. Consolidates legacy AII and OER systems, minimizes customization, and aligns with SAP S/4HANA and industry standards; reducing total cost of ownership while preparing businesses for evolving regulatory and operational demands.

 

What are the use cases of SAP Corporate Serialization?

SAP Corporate Serialization delivers flexible, industry-specific solutions that transform traceability from a compliance requirement into a strategic advantage. In automotive, it tracks EV batteries and safety-critical components throughout production and service lifecycles. Aerospace and defense benefit from full traceability of iUID-marked parts to meet stringent regulatory standards.

Consumer products leverage the platform to authenticate goods, combat counterfeiting, and engage buyers through digital product passports, while managing reusable assets like beverage kegs. In consumer electronics, it ensures serialization of devices, components, and software licenses, supporting traceability, warranty tracking, and fraud prevention. Tobacco and beverage industries use SAP Corporate Serialization to manage serial numbers linked to tax stamps and track premium or returnable products; ensuring compliance, authenticity, and streamlined reuse.

The hi-tech, utilities, and specialty gas sectors gain precise tracking of high-value components, spare parts, and cylinders, improving asset visibility, safety, and operational efficiency. In agribusiness, each pallet or shipment is tagged with a unique serial number, capturing its journey from harvest to delivery; enhancing logistics, inventory accuracy, and supply chain transparency.

Healthcare and medical device companies benefit from UDI compliance and post-sale serialization, linking components to digital service records to optimize lifecycle management, anticipate maintenance, and strengthen customer trust.

Across all these sectors, SAP Corporate Serialization proves its scalability and adaptability, supporting both compliance-driven and value-driven business outcomes, while turning traceability into a driver of efficiency, trust, and growth.

 

What is the business value of SAP Corporate Serialization?

Transitioning to SAP Corporate Serialization is not just about staying supported beyond 2027; it’s a strategic move that transforms traceability into a driver of efficiency, visibility, and growth. The platform operates in the background like an autopilot, automating serial number management operations, which improving employee productivity and freeing QA, logistics, and customer service teams to focus on exceptions, while providing instant access to service histories.

By centralizing serialized data, it reduces compliance and risk management costs, streamlines QA and RA workflows, and provides fully traceable records for audits. During recalls, affected products or components are identified quickly and precisely, minimizing operational disruption and waste.

Beyond operational gains, SAP Corporate Serialization safeguards brand reputation and drives sales. End-to-end traceability ensures authenticity, combats counterfeiting, and builds consumer trust, while digital experiences like product passports enhance engagement and encourage repeat purchases; protecting both brand and revenue.

Conclusion

The adoption of SAP Corporate Serialization is far more than a system upgrade; it’s a strategic investment in resilience, transparency, and long-term competitiveness. As the 2027 deadline approaches, the companies that act now will not only secure compliance but also unlock new value through lower costs, greater agility, and stronger consumer trust.

The question is no longer if serialization will redefine your supply chain, but how fast you can position your business to lead. Our team stands ready to partner with you; bringing best practices and proven expertise to ensure a seamless transition and help you capture the full potential of an intelligent product traceability ecosystem.

Learn how leading companies leverage SAP Corporate Serialization to achieve end-to-end product traceability, reduce operational complexity, and drive business resilience.

entry.title: Intelligent Supply Chains in Action: Fujitsu’s Agentic AI Approach to Global Trade Challenges
entry.content:
Introduction

Across industries, supply chain disruptions have become the new normal. Global manufacturers are navigating a complex web of challenges, including shifting trade policies, volatile energy prices, climate-driven events, and the growing demand for sustainable operations. The systems and strategies that once brought stability now struggle to keep up with this constant change.

According to a 2024 report by Maersk, 76% of respondents reported experiencing supply chain disruptions, and a startling 58% of them reported that the costs exceeded their predictions. From sudden tariff changes that reshape sourcing decisions to unexpected raw material shortages or port closures, disruptions no longer come one at a time as they overlap, compound, and evolve faster than traditional planning tools can respond.

In this environment, organisations need more than data visibility. They need decision intelligence systems that can sense change, learn continuously, and act responsibly in real time. This cannot be achieved in isolation, and an ecosystem or network play is a must. This is also where the latest innovations in Artificial Intelligence, like Agentic AI, can help redefine supply chain resilience.

The role of Agentic AI in Supply Chain Resilience

Agentic AI has the potential to power the next evolution of intelligent supply chain management. Instead of waiting for analysts or planners to interpret data, AI agents can continuously monitor supply, logistics, and market signals and then autonomously simulate and recommend the best response.

A few scenarios include:

  • Sudden geopolitical tensions? AI agents instantly recalculate costs, identify alternate suppliers, and propose optimised procurement mixes.
  • An energy-price surge? AI agents can suggest shifting production to lower-cost facilities or off-peak hours to protect margins and emissions goals.

SAP and its partner ecosystem are harnessing the power of Agentic AI to bring the vision of an intelligent supply chain to life. As a strategic SAP partner, Fujitsu is at the forefront of this innovation - creating next-generation solutions that enhance visibility, resilience, and responsiveness across global value networks.

Among the many factors disrupting supply chains today, cross-border tariffs remain one of the most complex and persistent challenges. In this article, we explore how Fujitsu’s Agentic AI-driven offerings are designed to help businesses anticipate, adapt to, and overcome these disruptions - enabling a smarter, more connected, and future-ready supply chain.

Building a Resilient Supply Chain to respond to Trade disruptions

In recent months, global trade dynamics have become increasingly unpredictable. The rules that once made it easy for goods to flow across borders - like free trade agreements - are now being challenged by new tariffs, shifting political alliances, and unexpected disruptions across the trade lanes. In a recent study published by BCG in 2025, it is estimated that at least 20% to 30% of EBIT margins for companies across all manufacturing sectors are at risk from higher tariffs!

Real-World Example: How Agentic AI Transformed a Global Electronics Manufacturer

A leading global electronics manufacturer in Asia faced significant challenges stemming from supply chain uncertainties, siloed enterprise systems and fragmented data. Their complex IT landscape made it difficult to access and interpret critical information across departments, slowing down decision-making during high-stakes disruptions.

Traditional point-to-point data integration approaches would have taken years to unify these disparate systems. Instead, the company sought a transformative solution - one that could consolidate enterprise data, enrich it with industry and business context, and dramatically accelerate decision cycles.

Agentic AI proved pivotal in transforming the company’s response to disruptions.

During disruptions such as trade tariffs or natural disasters like earthquakes, the manufacturer needed to rapidly assess the impact across their supply chain. This required synthesising internal enterprise data with external sources such as demographic trends, trade data, and harmonised system (HS) codes to simulate scenarios and take informed action.

As part of a broader digital transformation initiative, the company explored how Agentic AI could address supply chain shortages. By deploying intelligent agents across multiple systems - procurement, sales, inventory, and orchestration - they enabled real-time data access and contextual decision-making. These agents were trained to perform specialised tasks and provide actionable recommendations to business users.

For example, in the case of a raw material shortage, agents could evaluate multiple alternatives:

  • Sourcing from an alternative supplier,
  • Adjusting production schedules based on material availability, or
  • Engaging with customers to reschedule orders while maintaining service levels.

Each scenario required granular simulation across millions of SKUs, factoring in product, customer, and supplier contexts. The orchestrator agent played a pivotal role by assessing each option through the lens of cost, priority, and service level, ultimately recommending the most optimal path forward.

This innovative use of Agentic AI not only enhanced agility and collaboration across the enterprise but also earned a global recognition. The World Economic Forum’s AI Governance Alliance acknowledged this solution as one of 18 advanced AI applications transforming business worldwide.

Turning Data into Decisions

Expanding data visibility across enterprise, market, and regulatory sources enhances predictive accuracy and resilience.

Some other examples of how companies can use data and smart technologies to solve supply chain challenges encountered in tariff change scenarios are as follows:

  • Profit and Cost Analysis: By mapping out where costs are rising due to tariffs, companies can decide whether to pass those costs on to customers, absorb them, or find cheaper alternatives.
  • Pricing Simulations: Businesses can test how different prices will affect demand and profits in different tariff scenarios, helping them find the best balance between staying competitive and making money.
  • Operational Changes: If a key supplier is hit by a new tariff, companies can quickly see what other options are available, compare costs and quality, and make a switch if needed.

Fujitsu’s Multi-AI Orchestration Platform

Fujitsu has developed a Multi-AI agent orchestration platform for use cases such as Profit Margin & Cost Analysis that can leverage data stored in both SAP and non-SAP systems to present specific scenarios that can impact a customer’s supply chain. Using the simulation capabilities of this offering, multiple scenarios can be developed and compared, and the right strategy can be devised. The agentic AI platform leverages the data and helps to implement the decisions back into SAP applications like SAP S/4HANA SAP Integrated Business Planning and SAP Digital Manufacturing to effectuate the optimal plan chosen earlier. In the future, these agents could be extended to support SAP Business Network Supply Chain Collaboration and Supply Chain Orchestration as well.

These offerings are also complementary to the AI innovations delivered by SAP with the Business Suite e.g. seamless access with Joule, enhanced collaboration and decision making with SCM agents, etc.

Preparing for an AI-Enabled Future

Introducing technological capabilities isn’t enough. Companies also need to change the way they work with AI. This includes:

  • Cultivating an “AI-first” mindset: AI projects executed with a traditional mindset rarely deliver transformative outcomes. A transformational mindset is required to transform supply chains with AI. A few key aspects are as follows:
    • Myths like “AI will completely replace humans” are making way to “AI agents will work alongside humans”. But accepting this at an individual level requires humans to trust AI.
    • Especially within the supply chain, one cannot afford to have unreliable supply chain plans or manufacturing schedules. Balancing the level of AI autonomy with human empowerment is key to gaining this trust.
    • An AI-first and transformational mindset is required in transforming supply chains with AI
  • AI upskilling: Technologies such as Generative AI are being widely used by people to simplify their personal tasks. However, when it comes to corporate use of such tools, there are several nuances that we need to be aware of, like trusted tools, enterprise context and security concerns. These also apply specifically to the use of AI in supply chains
  • Improve Network relationships: A supply chain network includes partners like component suppliers, logistics partners etc. These partners are important to ensure optimal running of the supply chain in normal times and become critical during disruptions. Trusted data sharing, clear communication channels, and robust digital capabilities are critical to sustaining a resilient partner ecosystem

Conclusion

Agentic AI is redefining how organisations anticipate, adapt, and act amid global supply chain volatility. Fujitsu and SAP’s joint innovation demonstrates that the future of supply chain resilience lies not just in data, but in intelligent, autonomous collaboration.

Learn More

If you’d like to see how such technology can be turned into a solution in action or to learn more, consider attending the Fujitsu ActivateNow event in Singapore.
